definition:
A square matrix is said to be a *stable matrix* if every eigenvalue of
has negative real part. The matrix is called *positive stable* if every
eigenvalue has positive real part.

[*Motivation:*]{} In the following system of linear differential
equations, $$\mathbf{x}'(t) = M \mathbf{x}(t)$$ it is easy to see that
the point $\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}$ is an equilibrium point. The
trajectory $\mathbf{x}(t)$ will converge to $\mathbf{0}$ for every
initial value $\mathbf{x}(0)$ if and only if the matrix $M$ is a stable
matrix.
